It's not uncommon that people join charitable organisations for career reasons without embodying the ethos. Especially men in leadership positions are prone to abuse their power. However, it is not exculsively a male phenomenon - abuse was also frequently committed by nuns in orphanages of the Catholic Church. Only safeguarding policies, internal and external control as well as strict transparency procedures help. Ethical organisations could also pay part of their salaries as conditional bonus or additional pension which is forfeited in case of certain unethical  behaviour. In case of criminal behaviour legal procedures and investigations should be actively supported.
Please do.
Marianne Bergeron (les commentaires sont intéressants)

The behaviour of some ex-Oxfam workers are absolutely unacceptable and those responsible must be held accountable, including some in the leadership. But this is a demolition job that is intense and relentless coming from the anti-aid forces in the UK and US. This attack on Oxfam is an attack on the whole charity sector. Hold the fort, Oxfam. I'm sure a lot of us are by your side.

A few months ago Oxfam released a report on the unfairness of how wealth is distributed around the world. They said 82% of the wealth created last year went to the richest 1 % while the bottom half of the world got nothing! 

Now suddenly they are tangled up in a scandals involving their employees.. this isn't about concern for what happened. Indeed the story was in the public domain somewhat as the charity commission has a whif of it though not all. This is out because Oxfam upset some powerful people with their report and these people are now out to dismantle what is essentially one of the most powerful campaigners for social justice. Someone went digging for the right scandal and they found one. 
If Oxfam goes under there won't be anyone bothering the fat cats conscience... this is the same  things they are doing to the NHS... 

When a Doctor abuses patients the Government doesn't close the hospital, when a head teacher abuses children the Government doesn't withdraw funding from the school nor did we see the BBC deprived of tax cash because of the Jimmy Saville Scandal. Why are people calling for the Government to stop funding Oxfam?
I believe in oxfam and this wouldn't affect the gestures as world leading Humanitarian organization that fight injustice and promotes equality.

The types of people who work for aid agencies are the type who want free adventure, a wage for simi dosing, free travel, free sex from poor people who don`t take action or report. These types would not be able to hold down a job in a factory or office. Its a soft life, they seek fame and are glory holes, Jail the bastards and the ceo`s on 150,000 pounds per year.
Taking advantage of vulnerable people is simply not acceptable.
Will never get another penny off me.

It is sad that this happened to Oxfam, but I admire the honesty, transparency and humility of its leaders.  Very few organisations and leaders are brave enough to admit their problems and weaknesses and crimes committed by their people. Many will resort to "white washing" and cover-up just to protect the image of the organization. But Oxfam didn't resort to those options and bravely face the issue and stayed true to their advocacy of protecting women and the vulnerable sectors. And have those who committed the offense accountable so that justice be served to the offended.  Praying for strength for the people of Oxfam who are truly committed and honestly serving the vulnerable sectors of the society.  And may you truly deserve the people that you have and those you will choose to join Oxfam.

Great statement.
Oxfam will triumph!
The words ` I resign` seem to be missing from your statement.

In every organization similar issues arises at some point, some organization is just so good at managing their internal conflicts, just like inside a family structure.
It is never fair to condemn a whole organization with thousands of extra ordinary staff doing significant humanitarian work around the globe due mainly to the faults of some few greedy individuals who happens to work with OXFAM. 
OXFAM does not only help alleviate the sufferings of the communities affected by disasters and other injustice all over the world, their staffs (mostly hired locally) are equally empowered as well, in several ways. 
 In fact, I was one of the many who have realized the importance of a humanitarian work when OXFAM gave me an opportunity to help during the aftermath of Typhoon Haiyan which killed more than 6000 people in the Philippines. Before then, I was only idling in my home town doing day to day, insignificant contribution to humanity where I think at that point was just normal. But upon seeing the situation on the ground (devastation due to the typhoon), inspired by OXFAM, I realized I could have done more by improving first myself. 
After working with OXFAM I’ve worked hard to advance my education and fortunately with the help of a scholarship( not OXFAM) I just recently finished my master’s degree in one of the top universities in my country. 
My point is, you can put behind bars, the concern people who’ve tarnished the reputation of OXFAM but do not generalize and do not judge the whole organization ‘cause by doing so , you’ll reduce the chances of unprivileged  people like me( who’ve touched by OXFAM works) in the future, to empower themselves and I am just one of the few.
Your donations were never wasted with OXFAM, most of the time OXFAM goes to remote areas to reach people affected by disasters where other organizations dared not to, due to its inaccessibility( danger, distance to main roads and etc.)

Despite all these dirty allegations, I will still stand with Oxfam. They are doing a fantastic job. The bad apples will be dealt with. I really trust that Winnie Byanyima will take a stringent action on the culprits. But more importantly, a better system to address such issues should be put in place. Long live Oxfam.

Overall I am sure that Oxfam have made a positive difference to the world and this must not be forgotten. This scandal, however, is extremely dark and unsettling. It is also very surprising. It appears that money raised from kind souls has been misappropriated and spent on, allegedly, underage prostitutes. Prosecutions should have taken place.....and still should. These characters should be in jail. The damage that they have done has tarnished the name of Oxfam and it will not recover for years....if ever. I would not normally say such a comment but I genuinely hope that they suffer in hell for their actions.
As a director you should have known what was going on in your own charity it was your job and what you are paid for.

Hi Winnie,
Despite painful and sadness, I believe this can bring positive changes not only to Oxfam but also to the whole sector to protect women and (children) from any form of sexual abuse and exploitation. I am a female staff, working in a complex and conflicted affected country in Asia. I have found no other organisations that have this much strong safeguarding policy and practices as Oxfam has in place.I trust our safeguarding policy and practices that protect us and feel that I am safe and empowered. Please keep fighting against poverty and injustice. I am with you as a female staff.
It is difficult to believe in your organisation  after this disgusting allegation.

So, -
Why The Story now?
After all - this is Old news - because Oxfam - like the other charities - reported this themselves and promptly sacked those found out.
NONE of the media gave a damn ...
So - Why Now?

This month, Oxfam did a Bad Thing -
It began a campaign in which it started mentioning that the 1% had bagged 82% of the wealth created in '17 whilst the poorest got nothing. 
In short - Oxfam were taking on the message of Occupy.
Or: To quote former Charities Minister, Rob Wilson, they'd become -
"A front group for extreme leftwing Corbynistas'.

How convenient that this 'story' just as the Right Wing Media are demanding we stop sending money to 'Africa' because "Charity begins at home" - surely one of the most obscene bits of 'Selfishness parading as wisdom' ever voiced.

Yes, those who acted badly should be sacked (as they have been) and safeguards put in place(as they have been) but no-one is calling for this kind of oversight in any of the Businesses which make profits from Africa and which have a culture of sexual favours as part of their Executive - and lower - Hospitality. Oddly, in countries in which Sexual Tourism is the mainstay of the economy, there are no stories about the masses of white corporate employees who keep that industry afloat and NO calls for more safeguards and laws on this 'Free market' of women's bodies.
Don't you think there SHOULD be?

As Cimate Change increases, busineses buy up and evict whole populations, water is privatised and Oil Wars spread into everything, Oxfam - as well as all the other Charities -  are needed more now than ever.

DON'T let a Right-Wing campaign to take away Aid to countries which those of us in the '1st World' are STILL making a profit from just because they've managed to spin a 7-year old scandal into the engine for starving kids.

The Rich want to stop Charity. Everywhere.
We - surely - say - No.
Charity isn't a crime. Abuse is.
